His abdomen was tender and rigid along with a472lump in the inguinal region with purplish skin changes. Which of the following is the idealmanagement for this patient?

options.B: Conservative management with a nasogastric tube and IV fluid, assessment every 24 hrsPerform an oral contrast study, followed by pneumatic decompressiond) Endoscopic decompressionQuestion 5:A surgeon sees a necrotic bowel when operating on a child for an inguinal hernia. questions.explanation: The given clinical vignette is suggestive of intestinal obstruction, due to a strangulated inguinalhernia. The ideal management is exploratory laparotomy as soon as possible with ongoingresuscitative measures until surgery.Bowel strangulation is a type of mechanical bowel obstruction, associated with complete cessationof blood supply leading to irreversible loss of viability of the affected bowel segment. Inguinalhernias, most commonly of non-reducible type, are associated with a high chance of strangulationand need urgent medical intervention.Bowel strangulation can be suspected in the presence of• constant severe abdominal pain,• abdominal tenderness with rigidity and peritonism,•signs of shock, and lack of response to conservative management.• Reduced bowel wall enhancement on CTWhen strangulation occurs in an external hernia, the lump is tense, tender, and irreducible withoverlying skin changes (erythema or purplish discoloration).Supportive management:• IV fluids.• Nasogastric tube to decompress the bowel and reduce abdominal distention• IV antibiotics (adequate coverage required for gram -ve and anaerobes)486•AnalgesiaDefinitive management:•Continue supportive management up to 72 hrs if suspicious of adhesions. Surgical explorationand adhesiolysis should be done if there is no improvement.• Immediate surgical exploration and resection of non-viable gut segments if suspicious of any ofthe following:• Obstructed external hernia• Clinical features suspicious of intestinal strangulation• Obstruction in a ‘virgin' abdomen (i.e no prior history of intraabdominal surgery)

questions.question: A 5-year-old child who underwent an appendicectomy is brought to the emergency withabdominal distension and vomiting. The mother tells that the child passed stools that lookedlike currant jelly. The ultrasound finding is shown below. What is the most likely location ofthis pathology in this child?IGE-6TRANSVERSELONG AXIS-81 L 3.44 cm473
questions.explanation: The clinical vignette and the USG showing the doughnut sign (target sign) are suggestive ofpostoperative intussusception and the most likely location is ileoileal in postoperative cases.Intussusception occurs when a portion of the alimentary tract is telescoped into an adjacentsegment. The most common location of intussusception is ileocolic. However, ileoileal is the mostcommon location of intussusception postoperatively and in Henoch-Schönlein Purpura.Causes of intussusception are:••Idiopathic (most common cause in children)Pathological lead points such as enlarged submucosal Peyer's patch, lymphoma, intestinal polyp,leiomyomas, etc.• Meckel's diverticulum•A recent upper GI or respiratory infection, rotavirus vaccination has also shown someassociation with intussusception in children.The characteristic clinical triad includes:• Pain• Palpable sausage-shaped mass487• Red currant jelly stoolsUSG findings in intussusception include:• Target sign (also known as the doughnut sign)- The appearance is generated by concentricalternating echogenic (submucosa and serosa) with hypoechogenic bands (muscularis propria).••Pseudokidney sign: this is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel:the edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma and⚫ the mesentery which is dragged into the intussusception resembles the renal hilum.•• Crescent in a doughnut sign.Barium enema shows the characteristic coiled spring appearance.Treatment:•Reduction of intussusception should be done immediately after the diagnosis.• Radiologic hydrostatic reduction has a success rate of 80-95% in cases of ileocolicintussusception• Surgical reduction is only done in the presence of refractory shock, suspected bowel necrosis orperforation, peritonitis, and multiple recurrences.3aThe above image shows the coiled spring appearance3b

questions.question: A 3-day-old neonate presents with abdominal distension and bilious vomiting. An erect X-rayof the abdomen is done and shown below. The neonate is taken up for surgery and anapple-peel bowel with loss of dorsal mesentery is seen. Which type of ileal atresia has thisfeature?
questions.explanation: The given image showing a triple bubble appearance and associated finding of apple-peel bowelwith loss of dorsal mesentery is a feature of type 3 ileal atresia.Small bowel atresias present with intestinal obstruction soon after birth. Bilious vomiting is thedominant feature in jejunal atresia whereas abdominal distension is more with ileal atresia.488Plain abdominal radiographs show a variable number of dilated loops of bowel and fluid levelsaccording to the level of obstruction.• Jejunal/ileal atresia - Triple bubble appearance• Duodenal atresia - Double bubble appearanceA contrast study is the next best investigation to exclude other bowel anomalies.In jejunal/ileal atresia, the distal end of the dilated proximal small bowel is resected and a primaryend-to-end anastomosis is possible. If the proximal bowel is extremely dilated, it may need to betapered to the distal bowel before anastomosis.Classification of Jejunoileal atresia:TypeFeatureTypeMucosal web or diaphragm1Type2With an atretic cord betweentwo blind ends of bowel withintact mesenteryType3 aType3 bType4Complete separation of the blind ends of the bowel by a V-shaped mesenteric gapAnapple peelorChristmas tree deformitywith a large mesenteric gapMultiple atresias, with a string of sausage appearanceClassification of Jejunoileal atresiaMucosal web or diaphragmZstratio dondintootmosentoryBlind ondof bowelTYDO IllaV-shaped mesenterio dapTYPO IbTYPE4438ADDla pont or Christmastroo deformityuapManiple atresia or string ofSaunadoappearanoo489Type IVType IType IIType IIIAType IIIB

questions.question: A child with complaints of abdominal pain and vomiting for the past 24 hours associated withtenderness over McBurney's point undergoes open appendicectomy. However, duringsurgery, the appendix was found to be normal. On exploration of the ileum, the followingfinding is seen. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?474

options.A: It is a lead point for intussusception
options.B: Gastric mucosa is the most common heterotropic tissue
options.D: Located 60 cm proximal to ileocecal valve

questions.explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of Meckel's diverticulitis. It arises from the antimesenteric borderof the small intestine.Meckel's diverticulum is the most commonly encountered congenital anomaly of the smallintestine. Meckel's diverticulum is caused by a failure of normal regression of the vitelline duct oromphalomesenteric duct that develops during weeks 5 to 7 of gestation. It contains all 3 layers ofthe intestine and hence it is a true diverticulum.It is located 45 to 60 cm proximal to the ileocecal valve. The most common heterotopic tissuewithin the Meckel's diverticulum is gastric mucosa (50%) followed by pancreatic mucosa(5%) andcolonic mucosa.Most Meckel's diverticula are benign and are incidentally discovered. Its clinical features include:• Gastrointestinal bleeding (most common)• Intestinal obstruction, which may occur as:• Volvulus••Intussusception (ileo-ileal or ileo-colic)• Incarcerated Littre's hernia.Complications of Meckel's diverticulum are:• Diverticulitis - presents like appendicitis• Perforation - resembles a perforated duodenal ulcer• Peritonitis• Neoplasms - neuroendocrine tumour (most common) > adenocarcinoma > GIST >lymphoma.490MesenteMesenteryMeckel's diverticulumOMARROWMeckel'sdiverticulumAntimesentericborder

questions.question: What is the most common presentation of Meckel's diverticulum?
questions.explanation: The most common presentation of Meckel's diverticulum is lower gastrointestinal bleeding.Clinical features of Meckel's diverticulum include:••Lower GI bleeding (most common in children and overall)• Abdominal painVomitingAnother common presentation is an intestinal obstruction (most common in adults), which mayoccur due to:• Volvulus• Intussusception (ileo-ileal or ileo-colic)• Incarcerated Littre's hernia.

questions.question: Which of the following cannot be used to increase the sensitivity of the Tc-pertechnate scan inMeckel's diverticulum?
questions.explanation: Metoclopramide is not used to increase the sensitivity of the Tc-pertechnate scan in Meckel'sdiverticulum.Metoclopramide stimulates gastric motility and decreases the time available for the uptakeof Tc-pertechnate. Hence it reduces sensitivity.99mTc-pertechnetate is preferentially taken up by the mucus-secreting cells of the gastric mucosaand ectopic gastric tissue.The sensitivity of the Tc-pertechnate scan is increased by:491•Glucagon: Relaxes the smooth muscles of the gastrointestinal tract. This decreases peristalsis,causing enhanced detection of the ectopic gastric mucosa in Meckel's diverticulum• Pentagastrin: Potent stimulator of gastric secretions. Increases uptake and secretion ofpertechnetate by the gastric mucosa●Cimetidine: Increases radionuclide uptake, and decreases peptic secretion and the release ofpertechnetate from the diverticular lumen. This results in higher radionuclide concentrations inthe wall of the diverticulum.

questions.question: What will be the investigation of choice in a child suspected to have Meckel's diverticula?
questions.explanation: The investigation of choice in a child suspected to have Meckel's diverticulum isa 99mTc-pertechnetate radionuclide scan.The radionucleotide is preferentially taken up by the mucus-secreting cells of the gastric mucosaand ectopic gastric tissue in the diverticulum.In adults, there is a reduced prevalence of ectopic gastric mucosa. Hence it is lessaccurate and barium studies are preferred.The image below depicts a 99mTc radionuclide scan showing Meckel's diverticulum.Rneckel'stc04anteriorANT 40 MINMost of the Meckel's diverticula are discovered incidentally. In the absence of bleeding, Meckel'sdiverticula are rarely diagnosed prior to the time of surgical intervention.Other investigations for Meckel's diverticulum:• Angiography is used to locate the site of bleeding in an acute hemorrhage.• CT scan has a very low sensitivity.•Enteroclysis has an accuracy of 75% but is usually not applicable during acute presentations.492

questions.question: While performing an inguinal hernia repair in a 3-year-old boy, you notice Meckel'sdiverticulum as the content of the hernial sac. What is this hernia called?
questions.explanation: Meckel's diverticulum found in inguinal or femoral hernial sacs is known as Littre's hernia. It cancause intestinal obstruction.Littre's hernia©MARROWHernial sacMeckel'sdiverticulumOption A: Amyand's hernia is an inguinal hernia in which the hernia sac contains a normal oracutely inflamed appendix.Option B: Narath's hernia is seen in patients with congenital dislocation of the hip. It is a femoralhernia seen behind the femoral vessels.Option C: Cloquet's hernia is a type of femoral hernia where the sac lies under the pectineusfascia.

questions.question: While performing a laparotomy, the surgeon incidentally notices a narrow-mouthed,thickened Meckel's diverticulum. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.explanation: In a narrow-mouthed, thickened Meckel's diverticulum, resection of the diverticulum is thetreatment of choice.When Meckel's diverticulum is found in the course of abdominal surgery:• In cases of narrow-mouthed, thickened Meckel's diverticulum, resection of the diverticulum isthe treatment of choice• If it has a wide mouth and is not thickened, it can safely be left alone.Rarely, Meckel's diverticulum is complicated by a meso-diverticular band, which is believed to bea remnant of a vitelline artery. In such symptomatic cases, the treatment is diverticulectomy withthe removal of associated bands connecting the diverticulum to the abdominal wall or intestinalmesentery.Segmental resection of the ileum that includes both the diverticulum and the adjacent ileal pepticulcer should be performed if:•There is bleeding from the diverticulum493• The base is inflamed or perforated• The diverticulum contains a tumour.

questions.question: What is the most common site for acquired diverticula in the small intestine?
questions.explanation: The most common site for acquired diverticula in the small intestine is the second part ofthe duodenum (Windsock's diverticulum).The colon is the most common site for acquired/false diverticula overall, followed by theduodenum.Meckel's diverticulum is the most common true congenital diverticulum of the small bowel.A barium swallow showing a well-defined diverticulum in the second part of the duodenum(Windsock's diverticulum) is shown below.

questions.question: A 38-year-old man presents with dull aching abdominal pain for the past few weeksaccompanied by loss of weight and appetite. A barium meal follow-through image is shownbelow. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario along with the barium study showing a shrunken caecumpulled-up away from the right iliac fossa is most likely suggestive of intestinal tuberculosis.The most common site of intestinal tuberculosis is the distal ileum and cecum.494ShrunkenCaecumIleocaecal TuberculosisIC junctionString signDilatedproximal ileumThe yellow color arrow marks indicate the shrunken caecum, stricturous narrowing of theterminal ileum and ileocaecal junction, and proximal ileal dilatation.

questions.question: A respiratory therapist presents to the OPD with abdominal pain. He also complains oflow-grade fever, night sweats, and loss of weight. You investigate him for intestinaltuberculosis. Which of the following radiological signs are expected to be seen in him?
questions.explanation: Creeping fat sign and apple core sign are not the radiological findings seen in intestinaltuberculosis.The creeping fat sign refers to the widely separated bowel loops due to fibrofatty proliferationseen in Crohn's disease.The apple core sign describes a short segment irregular circumferential stricture of the largebowel that has abrupt shouldered margins resembling an apple core. This appearance isclassically seen in a stenosing annular colon carcinoma.495

questions.question: A young man presented with pain abdomen, diarrhoea, and fever gradually increasing in astep ladder pattern over the past 2 weeks. A Widal test confirmed the diagnosis and he wasadmitted. A few days later, he developed intestinal perforation and was taken up forexploratory laparotomy. Which of the following findings would you see in this patient?
questions.explanation: Typhoid causes longitudinal ulcers.Typhoid fever is caused by Salmonella typhi. It presents with step-ladder fever and abdominalpain after an incubation period of 10-20 days. Over the next week, the patient can develop:• Distension• Diarrhoea• Splenomegaly•Characteristic rose spots on the abdomen caused by a vasculitisSurgical complications of typhoid are:•Paralytic ileus• Intestinal haemorrhage• Free ileal perforation (characteristically occurs during the third week of the illness)•⚫ Cholecystitis• Longitudinal ulcers (usually situated in the distal ileum)Diagnosis of typhoid is confirmed by culture of blood or stool.Treatment is by antibiotics, usually chloramphenicol.Perforation requires surgery to wash out and close the ulcer. Intestinal resection is usuallyavoided. In unstable patients, with evidence of septic shock, the bowel should be exteriorized andthe perforation closed after recovery. Paratyphoid infection also resembles typhoid fever and istreated in a similar manner.496Note: Transverse ulcers with stricture formation are seen in tuberculosis.

questions.question: A lady underwent a left hemicolectomy for colon cancer 5 days back. She now complains ofabdominal discomfort and bloating. She is still unable to pass gas. On examination, theabdomen is distended and no bowel sounds are heard. X-ray shows gas-filled loops ofthe intestine with multiple air fluid levels. Which of the following will be part of themanagement plan of the patient?
questions.explanation: The given post-op scenario after 72 hours of laparotomy with no passage of flatus, absent bowelsounds, and X-ray findings are suggestive of paralytic ileus. Initiation of oral intake andemergency laparotomy is not done in paralytic ileus.The return of normal motility post-surgery occurs in the following sequence:Small intestine (within the first 24 hours) → Stomach (within 48 hours) → Colon (3 to 5 days).Paralytic ileus is an adynamic/functional obstruction in which there is a failure of transmission ofperistaltic waves. This is secondary to neuromuscular failure in the myenteric (Auerbach's) andsubmucous (Meissner's) plexuses. Since there are no rigorous contractions, there is no colickypain.The resultant stasis leads to the following clinical features:• Abdominal distension marked and tympanitic••• Effortless vomiting• Absence of bowel sounds• Absolute constipationParalytic ileus takes on clinical significance if any of the following are observed at 72 hours afterlaparotomy after handling of the bowel:• No return of bowel sounds on auscultation• No passage of flatusRadiologically, the abdomen shows gas-filled loops of the intestine with multiple air fluid levels inan erect X-ray. A CT scan is more accurate for differentiating functional from mechanicalobstructionParalytic ileus is managed by nasogastric tube decompression and restriction of oral intake untilbowel sounds and the passage of flatus return. Electrolyte balance must be maintained.

questions.question: A 22-year-old male presents with purulent discharge from the umbilicus. He underwentlaparoscopic appendicectomy 6 months back. X-ray sinogram of the patient reveals anenterocutaneous fistula tract as shown below. Which of the following aids in the spontaneous478closure of the fistula?

options.B: Foreign body in the fistula tract

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and the X-ray sinogram showing a fistula tract connecting the skinopening and the small intestine are suggestive of an enterocutaneous fistula. In this case, it ismost likely due to the umbilical port used during appendicectomy.Fistula track length >2.5 cms is likely to heal. Enterocutaneous fistulas of length <2.5 cm areunlikely to heal and close.Enterocutaneous fistulas are classified according to their location and volume of daily output.These factors determine the treatment and mortality rates. Proximal fistulas are associated withhigher output, greater fluid and electrolyte loss. Distal fistulas tend to have lower output, making497them easier to manage and more likely to close spontaneously.Type of fistulaOutput/dayHigh-output fistula>500 mLIntermediate fistula200 - 500mLLow-output fistula<200 mL

questions.question: A 25-year-old man, who underwent exploratory laparotomy for acute abdomen develops afever on the 5th postoperative day. The sutured site is erythematous and on the removal oftwo skin sutures, there is a leakage of gastrointestinal contents through the wound. Anelectrolyte panel done shows hyponatremia, hypokalemia, and metabolic acidosis. What is theprobable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of an enterocutaneous fistula. From the electrolyte panelshowing hyponatremia, hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis, a diagnosis of duodenal fistula canbe made.The electrolyte abnormalities with gastric fistula are hypochloremia, hypokalemia, and metabolicalkalosis.Enterocutaneous fistulas are classified according to their location and volume of daily output.• Proximal fistulas are associated with higher output, greater fluid, and electrolyte loss, andgreater loss of digestive capacity.•Distal fistulas tend to have lower output, making them easier to manage and more likely to closespontaneously.Although both gastric and duodenal fistulas are proximal fistulas, duodenal fistulas receive anadditional 1 to 2 litres of enzymes, electrolytes, and water from the pancreatic and bile ducts.Hence duodenal fistulas are at greater risk for more electrolyte imbalance than gastric fistulas.The management of enterocutaneous fistula is based on well-established principles known asSNAP which includes:S - Sepsis elimination and skin protection• N - A period of parenteral nutrition may well be required•• A - Anatomical assessment⚫ P - Definitive planned surgery

questions.question: A 26-year-old bride-to-be presented with nausea, vomiting, and recurrent episodes ofpostprandial epigastric pain. She has lost nearly 25 kgs in the last 6 months to look good inher wedding dress. Proton pump inhibitors were tried but were unsuccessful. A barium meal479follow-through of the patient is given below. Which of the following is false about hercondition?

options.A: Weight gain is part of the management
options.B: Lying in prone position postprandially improves symptoms
options.D: The second part of duodenum is commonly involved

questions.explanation: The false statement about her condition is that the second part of the duodenum is commonlyinvolved.The given clinical scenario with rapid weight loss and the barium follow-through demonstratingdilation of the duodenum with an abrupt cut-off at its third part, coinciding with the line of thesuperior mesenteric artery is suggestive of superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome. The third498part of the duodenum is involved in SMA syndrome.SMA syndrome (also known as Wilkie's syndrome) is usually seen in young asthenic women. It isa rare condition characterized by compression of the third portion of the duodenum by the SMAagainst fixed retroperitoneal structures.SMA syndrome is associated with:•Rapid childhood growth• Profound weight loss• Abdominal surgery• Inflammatory diseases of the abdomen•Short ligament of Treitz• Immobilization in a cast that increases lordosis (cast syndrome)Its clinical features include:•Episodic vomiting•Profound nausea•Abdominal distention• Postprandial epigastric painUpper gastrointestinal barium swallow or hypotonic duodenography demonstrates abrupt ornear-total cut-off of the flow of barium from the duodenum to the jejunum. CT and magneticresonance (MR) arteriography can also be used for additional anatomical detail.The normal aortomesenteric angle is between 28-65 degrees. This is reduced to less than 25degrees in SMA syndrome. A CT scan showing the reduced aortomesenteric angle is given below:In SMA syndrome, initial conservative management includes:•• Frequent small feedings• Lying in a prone position or on the left side postprandially499•Weight gain (to increase mesenteric fat pad and thereby increase the aorto-mesenteric angle)• Removal of a body cast in cast syndromeLaparoscopic lysis of the ligament of Treitz is beneficial in few cases. If all the above treatmentsfail, duodenojejunostomy is done.AortaMThird portionof duodenumSuperior mesentericarteryAortaWilkie syndromeAnterior viewMACompressedduodenum-SuperiormesentericarteryLateral viewOMARROW

questions.question: A young male, who wishes to pursue his higher studies abroad gets a chest X-ray done as apart of the immigration clearance. X-ray shows air under bilateral domes of the diaphragm.He is currently asymptomatic with normal vital signs. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with an asymptomatic patient having air under the diaphragm withoutevidence of peritonitis (sterile pneumoperitoneum) is suggestive of pneumatosis intestinalis.Pneumatosis intestinalis presents as multiple gas-filled cysts of the gastrointestinal tract. It isusually located in the subserosa, submucosa, and rarely the muscularis layer.The common sites are jejunum > ileocecal region > colon. It represents one of the few casesof sterile pneumoperitoneum.Pneumatosis in neonates is usually associated with necrotizing enterocolitis.Predisposing factors include:•Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease• Immunocompromised state• Inflammatory, obstructive, or infectious conditions of the intestine• Endoscopy and jejunostomy• Ischemia• DiabetesPatients can be asymptomatic. Symptoms if present, is usually nonspecific like:• Diarrhoea• Abdominal pain500• Abdominal distention• Nausea, vomiting•Weight loss• Mucus in stoolDiagnosis can be made on the basis of:•Plain X-ray showing radiolucent areas within the bowel wall (appear as grape-like clusters or tinybubbles)• Barium contrast⚫ CT studiesTreatment involves:• Management of the uncomplicated primary disease.• When symptoms demand treatment, the first line is intermittent high flow oxygen therapy,providing a concentration of 70% continuously for 5 days by nasal specula.•• The cysts may also resolve with antibiotics, particularly metronidazole.• In resistant cases, maintenance treatment with sulfasalazine may be helpful. The prognosis inmost patients is that of the underlying disease.

questions.question: A 55-year-old man with IHD presents with sudden, severe, generalized abdominal pain andmultiple episodes of vomiting. On examination, the pulse rate is 118bpm, rhythm isirregularly irregular, BP is 90/60 mmHg. The abdomen appears soft, non-distended, andbowel sounds are absent. Which of the following could be a likely diagnosis in this case?480
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of a patient with sudden onset severe abdominal pain which isout-of-proportion to the physical examination findings along with atrial fibrillation is suggestive ofacute mesenteric ischemia.Mesenteric ischemia may be acute or chronic. The superior mesenteric artery (SMA) is most likelyaffected. An embolus is the most common cause of SMA occlusion. Possible sources for SMA501emboisation include:• Left atrium in atrial fibrillation• Previous history of ischemic heart disease/myocardial infarction•Vegetations on mitral and aortic valves associated with endocarditis• An atheromatous plaque from an aortic aneurysm.Other causes of mesenteric ischemia include:• Atherosclerosis of mesenteric vessels• Vasculitides• Venous thrombosis in factor V Leiden mutation• Non-occlusive mesenteric ischemia due to alterations in splanchnic blood flow.The most important clue to an early diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia is the sudden onsetof severe abdominal pain in a patient with atrial fibrillation or atherosclerosis. The pain istypically in the central abdomen and out of proportion to the physical findings.Associated clinical features include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal distension, peritonitis,and the passage of bloody stools.The gold standard for the diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia is angiography, andmanagement is laparotomy. The goal of operative exploration is to resect the compromisedbowel and restore blood supply via embolectomy.Other options:Option B: A pulsatile abdominal mass is seen in the case of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Acutepain and hypotension occur with rupture of the aneurysm, which requires an emergencyoperation.Options A and D: Acute severe pancreatitis and peptic ulcer perforation have no association withatrial fibrillation. They usually present with pain over the upper abdomen associated withguarding and rigidity on examination.

questions.question: What is the minimum dose of radiation that can cause radiation enteritis of the smallintestine?
questions.explanation: The minimum radiation dose in the small intestine that can cause radiation enteritis is 4500cGy.Radiation enteritis is a common complication of radiation treatment aimed at the abdomen andpelvis. It causes diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, and stomach cramps.The amount of radiation appears to correlate with the probability of the development of radiationenteritis. In general, serious late complications are unusual if the total radiation dosage is lessthan 4000 cGy. Morbidity risk increases with dosages exceeding 5000 cGy.The table below shows various parts of GIT and the radiation doses that can cause enteritis.Part of GITEsophagusRadiation dose (in cGy)6000 to 7500502Part of GITStomachRadiation dose (in cGy)4500 to 5000Small intestine & colon 4500 to 6500Rectum5500 to 8000

questions.question: A patient who is a known case of Crohn's disease underwent ileal resection for a stricture.Which of the following is not a part of the management of postoperative complications in thispatient?
questions.explanation: Administration of folic acid is done in jejunal resection. Ileal resection causes vitamin B12deficiency which requires administration of parenteral vitamin B12.Extensive resection of the small intestine (<150 cm of remaining small intestine) can result inmetabolic and nutritional consequences. This is known as short bowel syndrome. Thepresentation of the patient is dependent upon the site and extent of intestinal resection.The ileum is the only site of absorption of vitamin B12 and bile salts. Following resection of theileum, the loss of bile salts increases resulting in fat malabsorption and diarrhea. Othercomplications of resection include:••Peptic ulcers Due to gastric hypersecretion-Cholelithiasis - Due to interruption of the enterohepatic cycle of bile saltsInitial treatment priorities include repletion of fluid and electrolytes lost in severe diarrhoea byinitiating TPN. Long-term management involves:• Administration of oral cholestyramine to bind with bile salts• Dietary fat restriction• Parenteral vitamin B12•Proton pump inhibitors to lower gastric pH• Octreotide to reduce the volume of GI secretions• Antimotility agents such as loperamide hydrochloride to delay small-intestinal transitSmall intestine lengthening procedures done to increase absorption and transit time are:.• Longitudinal intestinal lengthening and tailoring procedure (LILT)• Serial transverse enteroplasty procedure (STEP)Intestinal transplantation is indicated only in complicated cases.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about the Tillaux sign?

options.A: Mass is felt in the periumbilical region
options.C: Mass is mobile perpendicular to mesentery attachment line

questions.explanation: Tillaux's sign is said to be positive if the mass/swelling is mobile perpendicular to the mesenteryattachment line. Tillaux's sign is seen in a mesenteric cyst.Mesenteric cysts occur either in the small intestine (60%) or the colon (40%) and can be classifiedas the following:503•••Chylolymphatic (most common type)Enterogenous• Urogenital remnant• Dermoid•• Other causes: traumatic hematoma and cyst formation, tuberculous cold abscess of mesenteryand hydatid cyst of the mesenteryThey most commonly occur in adults with a mean age of 45 years. It is more common in femalesthan males (2:1). The most common presentation is a painless abdominal swelling near theumbilicus, which is smooth and not moving with respiration with Tillaux's triad:• Soft, smooth swelling in the umbilical region.Freely mobile in a direction perpendicular to the mesentery (Tillaux's sign)• Zone of resonance around the cystOther presentations include recurrent attacks of abdominal pain due to temporary impaction of afood bolus in a segment of the bowel narrowed by the cyst and vomiting.Complications of mesenteric cyst include torsion, rupture, infection and hemorrhage into thecyst.Ultrasonography and CT are used to demonstrate mesenteric cysts.Treatment:• Chlyolymphatic cyst is managed by enucleation.• Enterogenous cyst is managed by removal of the cyst with resection of the adjacent bowel as itarises as a diverticulum or duplication from the adjacent bowel.In cases where complete excision is not possible due to the close proximity to vital structures,partial excision or marsupialization should be performed.Tillaux's signAttachment ofthe mesenteryA mesenteric cyst moves freely in the direction of the arrows,i.e. at right angles to the attachment of the mesentery. This iscalled the Tillaux's sign.OMARROW504

questions.question: 481What is the investigation of choice in a patient suspected to have a small bowel tumor?
questions.explanation: Enteroclysis is the investigation of choice in patients with small bowel tumours.Enteroclysis is a barium study in which the contrast agent is put directly into the duodenumthrough a nasogastric tube.Continued infusion of 500 to 1000 mL of thin barium sulfate and methylcellulose suspension isdone and then viewed continuously with the use of either fluoroscopy or radiographs taken atfrequent intervals. This technique is a double-contrast procedure that allows detailed imaging ofthe entire small intestine.Enteroclysis has a sensitivity of over 90% in the detection of small bowel tumours and is theinvestigation of choice, particularly for tumours located in the distal small bowel.Advantages of enteroclysis:• The contrast is administered at a controlled rate directly in the small bowel, bypassing theregulatory action of the pylorus.• The entire small bowel is demonstrated in a distended state, allowing better diagnosis. As aresult of the dilatation, the following can be visualised:•Mild strictures• Small sinus tracts and fistulas• Minimal extrinsic compressions•Skip lesions•Proximal and distal extent of diffuse diseases.• The examination can be completed in 15–30 minutes, thus reducing patient waiting time.

questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents with complaints of breathlessness, dull aching abdominal pain,and diarrhea. On examination, his face and chest appear flushed. CT scan of the abdomenshows a tumor in the terminal ileum with liver metastasis. An increased levels of 5-HIAA isseen in a 24-hour urinary sample. Which of the following is false regarding the managementof this patient?

options.A: Surgery should be done as soon as the diagnosis is made.
options.B: MRI is the best method for staging of the disease.

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of carcinoid syndrome caused by a carcinoid tumour. Thebest method for the staging of a carcinoid tumour is the octreotide scan.They are neuroendocrine tumours of the gastrointestinal tract. They arise from theenterochromaffin cells. They metastasize early to the regional lymph nodes and the liver.Abdominal symptoms include:•• Pain• Abdominal distension• Lower GI bleedingMetastasis in these patients can cause increased production of serotonin leading to carcinoidsyndrome with features like:•Flushing• Diarrhoea505• Bronchospasm• Cardiac symptoms because of stenosis and insufficiency of the cardiac valvesThe diagnosis is made by an assessment of 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA) in a 24-hoururine sample. It is positive in larger tumours only if metastases are present.Ultrasonography, CT scan, and MRI may show the primary tumour and metastases. The bestmethod for staging carcinoid tumours is by octreotide scan or somatostatin receptor scintigraphy(SRS).Treatment:• Somatostatin and its analogues are used in the symptomatic treatment of carcinoid syndrome.• Surgery should be undertaken as soon as the diagnosis is made, even in the presence of livermetastases.• Resection of the primary tumour and mesenteric lymph node metastases is done..• In the presence of liver metastasis - liver resection, transarterial embolization (TAE),chemoembolization (TACE), chemotherapy, and liver transplantation can be done.

questions.question: Which of the following is a false statement about abdominal lymphoma?

options.A: MALT lymphoma is associated with H.pylori infection.
options.B: Primary small-intestinal lymphomas are most commonly located in the jejunum.
options.C: Lymphoma is the most common malignant neoplasm of spleen.
options.D: Stomach is the most common site for extranodal lymphoma.

questions.explanation: Primary small-intestinal lymphomas are most commonly located in the ileum.Option A:Primary gastric lymphomas are derived from B-cells and classified as diffuse large B-celllymphomas (DLBCL) and mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT). Both DLBCL and MALTare thought to be associated with chronic Helicobacter pylori infection. This linkage is betterestablished for MALT, whereas the association between H. pylori infection and DLBCL is morecontroversial.Option C:Lymphoma is the most common malignant neoplasm of the spleen.Option D:Gastric lymphoma accounts for the majority of extranodal lymphomas, representingapproximately 50-75% of primary gastrointestinal lymphomas.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding lymphoma of the small intestine?

options.B: It is the most common tumour of the small intestine in children
options.C: Resection is indicated in all symptomatic patients
options.D: Burkitt's lymphoma affects the ileocaecal junction482

questions.explanation: B-cell lymphomas are chemo-sensitive. T-cell lymphomas are chemo-resistant.Approximately one-third of GI lymphomas occur in the small bowel. In the small intestine, mostcommonly they are found in the ileum. In children <10 years, lymphomas are the most commonintestinal neoplasm. In adults, they constitute up to 25% of small bowel malignant tumours.Patients with celiac disease and immunodeficiency are at increased risk for the development ofprimary small intestine lymphomas.506Clinical features include:• Pain• Weight loss• Nausea• Vomiting•⚫ Bleeding•Change in bowel habits• Intestinal obstructionSmall intestine lymphomas are usually larger than 5 cm. They may extend into the mucosa.Microscopic examination shows diffuse infiltration of the intestinal wall.In the absence of symptoms, they are often chemo-responsive and do not require surgery.In symptomatic patients, resection is indicated.• B-cell lymphomas are more chemosensitive and have high remission rates, with or withoutsurgery.• T-cell lymphomas are more resistant to therapy and will progress to symptoms of obstruction orperforation if not resected.Small intestine lymphomas cause complications like haemorrhage and perforation. The bestprognostic indicator is a response to systemic therapy. The five-year survival rate is 50% to 60%Note:• The stomach (50-75%) is the most common site of lymphomas in the gastrointestinal system.• Burkitt's lymphoma can aggressively affect the ileocaecal region.• Lymphoma is the most common malignant neoplasm of the spleen.507
